CONGRATULATIONS,
MARYLAND!

autointoxi.

During the past few years, at
least, the only contacts between the
student bodies of Maryland and
Hopkins have been the yearly occasions when the rooters have been
banked on opposite sides of the
Stadium, howling defiance at each

other, or when they have been doing practically the same thing at the
lacrosse games in the spring. Clearly, this is not the way to form a
No use trying to rise and shine
while you're keeping yourself
half - dead from self - generated
poisons.
Put your system on a paying basis.
Keep your digestive organs functioning properly. Make an attempt
to balance your daily diet.

very favorable mutual opinion.
We do not wish to make any rash
predictions about the "beginning of
a new era," but the trip to College
Park of ten or more Hopkins men
to assist in the installing of a chapter of 0. D. K. at Maryland ought
to provide a basis for better relations. The fact that both colleges
have branches of the same honor
society, working for the same ends
and promoting the same ideals,
ought to pave the way for fuller
understanding.
We congratulate both the University of Maryland for receiving the

world suffiJt

cient unto its

outside

responsible for you being here—or maybe
they merely lend aid, sympathy and

charter and the individuals who have

at Hopkins.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 4, 1927

3

Dr. Robinson To
Lecture Monday
Howard & LexingtonS

Dr. David Moore Robinson, Professor of Archaeology, will lecture
Monday evening at the parish house
of the Emmanuel Protestant Episcopal Church, Cathedral and Read
Streets.
"New Light on the Early Christian Church from Excavations in
Asia Minor" will be the subject of
Dr. Robinson's talk.

DANIEL C. FAHEY, '28, Editor of
Reveille, Track team.
Dr. Pearson Interested

Dr. Pearson was greatly interested in the various aspects of 0. I).
K. and expressed a belief that the
society will be of great benefit to
the college. The delegates from
Hopkins were very cordially received and expressed an opinion
that the possession of a mutual organization between Hopkins and
Maryland would do much toward
improving relations between the two
institutions.

passenger is traveling with an
adorable female relative (word of six
letters). Amenities are now being
opened, and soon their conversation
will be sparkling like the dancing sun
rays on the deep Atlantic. That's
the thing about these Cunard College
Specials — birds of a feather flock together, and a good time is had by all.

He Threw This'Pen and

theJagged'Rocks a Half

Non-breakable Pen Barrel? Dr.
F.C. Morse of the National Parkto-Park Highway Association was
unconvinced.
So recently to test the new Parkcr
Duofold barrel, he stood on the
rim of Grand Canyon and threw
this pen into the rock-lined chasm.
When the pen was recovered
amid the jagged rocks a half mile
below the canyon's edge, it was
scratched a bit, but quite unbroken.
When the cap was removed the
point was as good as ever—a point
guaranteed for 25 ycars, not on17
for mechanical perfection but for
wear!
You cannot get Duofold quality
in any pen save that stamped
"Geo. S. Parker.'" Look carefully
for this. Any good pen counter
would like you to try this classic.

During the past few years, at
least, the only contacts between the
student bodies of Maryland and
Hopkins have been the yearly occasions when the rooters have been
banked on opposite sides of the
Stadium, howling defiance at each

other, or when they have been doing practically the same thing at the
lacrosse games in the spring. Clearly, this is not the way to form a
No use trying to rise and shine
while you're keeping yourself
half - dead from self - generated
poisons.
Put your system on a paying basis.
Keep your digestive organs functioning properly. Make an attempt
to balance your daily diet.

very favorable mutual opinion.
We do not wish to make any rash
predictions about the "beginning of
a new era," but the trip to College
Park of ten or more Hopkins men
to assist in the installing of a chapter of 0. D. K. at Maryland ought
to provide a basis for better relations. The fact that both colleges
have branches of the same honor
society, working for the same ends
and promoting the same ideals,
ought to pave the way for fuller
understanding.
We congratulate both the University of Maryland for receiving the

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 4, 1927

3

Dr. Robinson To
Lecture Monday
Howard & LexingtonS

Dr. David Moore Robinson, Professor of Archaeology, will lecture
Monday evening at the parish house
of the Emmanuel Protestant Episcopal Church, Cathedral and Read
Streets.
"New Light on the Early Christian Church from Excavations in
Asia Minor" will be the subject of
Dr. Robinson's talk.

Dr. Pearson Interested

Dr. Pearson was greatly interested in the various aspects of 0. I).
K. and expressed a belief that the
society will be of great benefit to
the college. The delegates from
Hopkins were very cordially received and expressed an opinion
that the possession of a mutual organization between Hopkins and
Maryland would do much toward
improving relations between the two
institutions.

Non-breakable Pen Barrel? Dr.
F.C. Morse of the National Parkto-Park Highway Association was
unconvinced.
So recently to test the new Parkcr
Duofold barrel, he stood on the
rim of Grand Canyon and threw
this pen into the rock-lined chasm.
When the pen was recovered
amid the jagged rocks a half mile
below the canyon's edge, it was
scratched a bit, but quite unbroken.
When the cap was removed the
point was as good as ever—a point
guaranteed for 25 ycars, not on17
for mechanical perfection but for
wear!
You cannot get Duofold quality
in any pen save that stamped
"Geo. S. Parker.'" Look carefully
for this. Any good pen counter
would like you to try this classic.
